      • assertTrueWithin

        public static void assertTrueWithin(BooleanEvaluator evaluator,
                                    long millisToWait,
                                    long millisIntervalToCheck)
        Asserts that the evaluator returns true with millisToWait. Checks every millisIntervalToCheck.
        Parameters:
        evaluator - boolean evaluator to call within the waiting period
        millisToWait - millis to wait before fail the assertion
        millisIntervalToCheck - interval of the calls to the evaluator

      • assertExceptionThrown

        public static void assertExceptionThrown(java.lang.Runnable code,
                                         java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.Throwable> exceptionClass)

        Asserts that the specified Exception (really, any Throwable) was thrown by the code encapsulated in a Runnable.

        For example: 
         assertExceptionThrown(new Runnable() { public void run() {
    agencyPaymentItem.reverse();
 } }, IllegalStateException.class);

        Will fail the test if the reverse() method doesn't throw an IllegalStateException.

        This'd be a lot nicer in Gosu with blocks.

        Parameters:
        code - a Runnable implementation with the code under assertion in the public void run() method
        exceptionClass - the class of the exception expected to be thrown in the code

      • assertExceptionThrown

        public static void assertExceptionThrown(java.lang.String failureMessage,
                                         java.lang.Runnable code,
                                         java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.Throwable> exceptionClass)

        Asserts that the specified Exception (really, any Throwable) was thrown by the code encapsulated in a Runnable.

        For example: 
         assertExceptionThrown("Expected the exception because blah blah blah",
     new Runnable() { public void run() {
       agencyPaymentItem.reverse();
 } }, IllegalStateException.class);

        Will fail the test if the reverse() method doesn't throw an IllegalStateException.

        This'd be a lot nicer in Gosu with blocks.

        Parameters:
        failureMessage - the message that will be displayed if this assertion fails
        code - a Runnable implementation with the code under assertion in the public void run() method
        exceptionClass - the class of the exception expected to be thrown in the code

      • assertExceptionThrownWithMessage

        public static void assertExceptionThrownWithMessage(java.lang.Runnable code,
                                                    java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.Throwable> exceptionClass,
                                                    java.lang.String expectedExceptionMessage)

        Asserts that the specified Exception (really, any Throwable) was thrown by the code encapsulated in a Runnable and the message from the exception matches the expected String exactly.

        For example: 
         assertExceptionThrown(new Runnable() { public void run() {
    agencyPaymentItem.reverse();
 } }, IllegalStateException.class, "Oops");

        Will fail the test if the reverse() method doesn't throw an IllegalStateException or the message doesn't match "Oops."

        This'd be a lot nicer in Gosu with blocks.

        Parameters:
        code - a Runnable implementation with the code under assertion in the public void run() method
        exceptionClass - the class of the exception expected to be thrown in the code
        expectedExceptionMessage - the text of the exception message that needs to match exactly

      • assertExceptionThrown

        public static void assertExceptionThrown(java.lang.Runnable code,
                                         IType exceptionType)

        Asserts that the specified Exception (really, any Throwable) was thrown by the code encapsulated in a Runnable.

        For example: 
         assertExceptionThrown(new Runnable() { public void run() {
    agencyPaymentItem.reverse();
 } }, IllegalStateException);

        Will fail the test if the reverse() method doesn't throw an IllegalStateException.

        This'd be a lot nicer in Gosu with blocks.

        Parameters:
        code - a Runnable implementation with the code under assertion in the public void run() method
        exceptionType - the type of the exception expected to be thrown in the code

      • assertExceptionThrownWithMessage

        public static void assertExceptionThrownWithMessage(java.lang.Runnable code,
                                                    IType exceptionType,
                                                    java.lang.String expectedExceptionMessage)

        Asserts that the specified Exception (really, any Throwable) was thrown by the code encapsulated in a Runnable and the message from the exception matches the expected String exactly.

        For example: 
         assertExceptionThrown(new Runnable() { public void run() {
    agencyPaymentItem.reverse();
 } }, IllegalStateException, "Oops");

        Will fail the test if the reverse() method doesn't throw an IllegalStateException or the message doesn't match "Oops."

        This'd be a lot nicer in Gosu with blocks.

        Parameters:
        code - a Runnable implementation with the code under assertion in the public void run() method
        exceptionType - the type of the exception expected to be thrown in the code
        expectedExceptionMessage - the text of the exception message that needs to match exactly

      • assertMethodDeclaredAndOverridesBaseClass

        public static void assertMethodDeclaredAndOverridesBaseClass(java.lang.Class myClass,
                                                             java.lang.String methodName,
                                                             java.lang.Class[] parameterTypes)
        Deprecated. If you're using this test, then you probably need to 1) remove the test and 2) remove the overriding behavior if a DM property is being overridden.
        Asserts that a method with methodName and parameterTypes exists on myClass, and that it does indeed override a method on a superclass. This assertion is especially useful in making sure overriden entity properties continue to be overriden and don't get lost (for example, during an entity refactor).
        Parameters:
        myClass - class name
        methodName - method name
        parameterTypes - method parameter types

        @Deprecated
public static <T> org.fest.assertions.CollectionAssert assertThatIteratorAsCollection(java.util.Iterator<T> actual)
        Deprecated. 
        PL-18421: Since converting an Iterator to a Collection consumes the Iterator elements it is preferable to make an explicit conversion rather than doing it inside an assertion. For example: assertThat(Lists.newArrayList(iterator))

      • assertBigDecimalEquals

        public static void assertBigDecimalEquals(java.math.BigDecimal expected,
                                          java.math.BigDecimal actual)

      • assertBigDecimalEquals

        public static void assertBigDecimalEquals(java.lang.String message,
                                          java.math.BigDecimal expected,
                                          java.math.BigDecimal actual)
        Uses BigDecimal.compareTo(BigDecimal) to determine if two BigDecimals are equal. Also, if one of the BigDecimals is null and the other is zero, this method considers them equal.
        Parameters:
        message - message used in error description
        expected - expected value
        actual - actualy value

      • assertBigDecimalNotEquals

        public static void assertBigDecimalNotEquals(java.lang.String message,
                                             java.math.BigDecimal expected,
                                             java.math.BigDecimal actual)
        Uses BigDecimal.compareTo(BigDecimal) to determine if two BigDecimals are not equal. If one of the BigDecimals is null, this assert will fail.

      • assertBigDecimalNotEquals

        public static void assertBigDecimalNotEquals(java.math.BigDecimal expected,
                                             java.math.BigDecimal actual)
        Uses BigDecimal.compareTo(BigDecimal) to determine if two BigDecimals are not equal. If one of the BigDecimals is null, this assert will fail.

      • assertHashtableContains

        public static <T> void assertHashtableContains(java.util.Map<T,T> expected,
                                               java.util.Hashtable<T,T> actual)
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of the key and value
        Parameters:
        expected - values that should be in the properties, whip one up with new HashMap<Object, Object>() {{ put("key", "value"); ... }}
        actual - The Properties you want to check - can have more properties!
